div1.p: Mosquito Control Ends Fatal Plague of Yellow Fever

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
MOSQUITO CONTROL
ENDS FATAL PLAGUE
OF YELLOW FEVER

Dr. Walter Reed Who Served
as Brooklyn Health Officer
Found Carrier of Germ.
By H. B. MAUER.

“The great pestilence of Virginia”
as it is historically known, was the
yellow fever plague, which almost
wiped out the entire population of
Portsmouth and Norfolk in 1855--a
time of general consternation, sud-
den death and hasty burials. Thou-
sands fled from their loved, peaceful
and previously happy and healthy
homes to escape a scourge which
annihilated whole families in the
palatial mansion as well as the
humblest hut. As compared with
the great scourage of London, with
its 100,000 fatalities, the ratio being
one death to seventeen survivors,
the death loss in Portsmouth and
Norfolk was one in three.

Omitting all harrowing details,
this brief reference to Virginia's
plague, it might be said that a de-
scription of it would be a descrip-
tion of the 90 other plagues which
had invaded the United States; one
in 1793 which took 10 percent of
Philadelphia's population: that of
New Orleans in 1853 with its 8,000
fatalities and with others in that
year which caused a loss of $15,335,-
000, when a dollar meant some-
thing; those of Memphis, Charles-
ton, Galveston, Baltimore and New
York even and the most outstand-
ing of them all, Panama, where De
Lesseps lost 22,000 of his men. The
purpose of this recital, however, is
to throw out in bold relief the
transcendentally splendid services of
Walter Reed and his colleagues.

On the western hemisphere, at
least, no longer does yellow fever lay
its victims low by thousands or to
any extent, for it has all but passed
into history and to Walter Reed,
more than to any other, is the credit
due for that colossal achievement.
Brooklyn Health Official.

Walter Reed was born at Belroi,
Gloucester County, Virginia, on
13, 1851. He began the study
of medicine at the University of
Virginia, graduating as an M. D. at
the age of 17. A second degree was
rred upon him by the Bellevue
Medical College of the City of New
after which he served in the
Brooklyn City Hospital and on
Blackwell's Island, now called Wel-
fare Island. Before he was 21 he
was a district physician in New
York City and at 22 was one of the
health inspectors of the Board of
Health of Brooklyn. He entered the
army as an assistant surgeon in
1875, ranking as first lieutenant, and
served in Arizona, Nebraska, Dakota
and in southern and western states.
In 1893 he was promoted surgeon
with the rank of major, when he
was detailed in Washington as
curator of the Army Medical Mu-
seum and professor of Bacteriology
in the Army Medical School.

During the Spanish - American
War, when yellow fever spread de-
vastation among American troops,
he was selected as the head of a
board to study the causes and
spread of the disease and afterwards
was sent to Cuba for the same pur-
pose. With him three other army
surgeons were associated, James
Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear and Aris-
tides Agramonte, who constituted a
Yellow Fever Commission.

About this time much work was
done by the American authorities
to diminish disease and mortality
in Cuba, and while these operations
produced a marked improvement
along some lines, they had no effect
whatever on yellow fever. It was
now that Reed suspected that the
transmission of the disease was due
to an insect, since all well estab-
lished sanitary measures proved
futile.

In 1881, Dr. Carlos Finley, of
Havana, advanced the theory that
a mosquito was the essential agent
for yellow fever transmission and
this claim now engaged the atten-
tion of Walter Reed. He also at
the same time effectually set at
rest another generally accepted
theory.

Supplies with ample funds to con-
duct experiments and volunteers
offering themselves aplenty from
among the American soldiers, this
experimentation now proceeded.

The first tests were negative. Men
of sound health were placed in beds
in which yellow fever patients had
died, without change of bedding;
they were clothed in unlaundered
garments which such victims had
worn and ate from their dishes, un-
washed; in fact, every possible test
was employed and no yellow fever
resulted. After exhausting every
possible means along these lines,
the experimenters were convinced
that yellow fever was not a con-
tagious disease. Positive tests were
now made by resorting to the mos-
quito transmission theory, but the
tests were first made on the mem-
bers of the commission themselves
since they were firmly convinced
that the means now to be employed
would produce the expected results,
they would not place the health and
lives of others in jeopardy.

Dr. Carroll allowed himself to
be bitten by a mosquito which was
known to have previously bitten a
yellow fever patient and the disease
resulted. He recovered, however, and
then Dr. Lazear made a like experi-
ment. At first, no ill effects came of
this, but a subsequent test proved
fatal and Dr. Lazear died. There
is a tablet placed to his memory
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital at
Baltimore, the inscription of which
was composed by Dr. Eliot, presi-
dent of Harvard University.

Many more experiments were
made chiefly on American soldiers,
who had first, however, been made
cognizant of Lazear's fate but this
did not deter them and on one
occasion, when two of these humble
obscure heroes presented themselves.
Kissinger and Moran by name, and
insisted that they would submit to
the tests for the good of humanity
and the advancement of science,
and disdained to take the $200
reward offered, as did also every
other volunteer, Major Reed said:
“Gentlemen, I salute you.”

Reed's claims were now so well
established that they received uni-
versal acceptance and thereafter all
efforts to stamp out yellow fever
were directed toward the mosquito,
